careTargets.gradient: Horizontal thermal gradient with basking zone (108-113Â°F surface temp) on one end and cool zone (77-85Â°F) on opposite end. Allows dragon to thermoregulate by moving between zones.

notes: Active, terrestrial lizard with climbing tendencies - provide sturdy branches
Known for friendly temperament and distinctive 'beard' display behavior
Diurnal sun-worshippers requiring extremely bright lighting and high UVB
Omnivorous - juveniles eat mostly insects, adults transition to 70-85% vegetables
Native to Australia's arid interior - warm days (basking 108-113Â°F) and cooler nights (55-75Â°F)
Adults should be fed sparingly to prevent obesity and gout (common US captive issues)
Natural burrowers - provide 4-6 inches of packed sand substrate for digging behavior

warnings.message: NEVER cohabitate bearded dragons - causes stress, fighting, serious injury, and death. Even females have dominance disputes. Males will fight viciously. One dragon per enclosure ONLY.
MINIMUM 6'x2'x2' for adults - smaller enclosures prevent proper thermoregulation. Bigger is always better (6'x3'x3' ideal). Juveniles under 12 inches can start in 4'x2'x2'.

UVB REQUIREMENT: T5 HO 10.0-12% bulb covering 50-70% of enclosure length. NO glass or plastic cover blocking UVB. Replace every 12 months regardless of visible light. Target UVI 4.0-4.5 at basking (verify with Solarmeter 6.5).

BASKING SETUP: Surface temp 108-113Â°F covering dragon's ENTIRE body including tail. Use at least 2 halogen flood bulbs side-by-side (90-100w total). Hot spots cause burns. Cool side must be 77-85Â°F for gradient.
NEVER use calcium sand, vitamin sand, or reptile carpet. Calcium sand causes impaction and neutralizes stomach acid. Reptile carpet harbors bacteria and traps toes/claws causing injury.
Replace UVB bulbs every 12 months for T5 HO - visible light does NOT mean UVB is working. Mark replacement date on calendar.
Loose substrate is SAFE for healthy dragons - impaction caused by dehydration, low temps, parasites (not substrate itself). Use fine sand, not calcium sand.
OVERFEEDING WARNING: Adults need mostly vegetables (70-85%) with insects only 2x/week. Too much protein causes gout and obesity - extremely common in US captive dragons.
Avoid woven hammocks - trap nails and toes causing broken limbs. Use sturdy branches or magnetic ledges instead for climbing.
DO NOT force regular baths - has laxative effect and encourages dehydration. Provide shallow water dish. Bathe no more than 1x/month unless medically necessary.
Certain morphs (hypomelanistic, translucent, silkback) are more UVB-sensitive - reduce to max UVI 3.0 at basking.
Invest in quality temperature monitoring: infrared temp gun for surface temps + digital probe thermometer for air temps. Both required for complete thermal picture.
Use surge protector for all heat lamps - protects against electrical fluctuations that cause premature bulb burnout.

feedingNotes: JUVENILES (<12 inches): 5-6 head-sized insects daily + vegetables daily (3x larger than insect volume). 60% protein diet.
ADULTS (>12 inches): 3-4 head-sized insects 2x/week + vegetables 3x/week (one portion = size of dragon's head). 15-30% protein diet.
Gutload all insects for 24 hours before feeding. Dust with calcium powder on all feedings.
Multivitamin powder on salads: 2x/week for juveniles, 1x/week for adults.
Good feeders: Dubia roaches, crickets, black soldier fly larvae, discoid roaches, hornworms, silkworms.
AVOID: Wild-caught insects (pesticides), mealworms as staple (low nutrition), insects larger than space between eyes.
Vegetables: Collard greens, mustard greens, turnip greens, bok choy, arugula, endive, spring mix. Soak in water 24-48 hours for hydration.
Fruit RARE TREATS only (1x/month max) - causes obesity and dental disease if fed regularly.
waterNotes: Provide shallow water dish at all times on cool side of enclosure.
Use tap water (NOT distilled, reverse osmosis, or softened water).
Change water 2-3x weekly minimum. Clean dish with F10SC or Rescue disinfectant.
Bearded dragons DO NOT absorb water through cloaca (myth) - must drink or get from food.
Dish should be shallow enough to prevent drowning but deep enough to not dry out quickly.
mistingNotes: DO NOT mist bearded dragons - they are arid species from Australian desert.
Ambient humidity 30-60% is correct. Brief spikes to 60%+ from plant watering are natural and safe.
Heat and humidity have inverse relationship - basking area will be 10% humidity, cool side higher.
Too-dry air (<30%) causes respiratory/skin issues. Too-wet substrate causes scale rot.
If live plants included, place on cool side to create humidity gradient.
